moves.1. d4: I played this game while listening to some '77 Dead, and I was able to really outclass the opposition.
moves.1... d5 2. c4 c6: Okay, so I think this is the Slav defence to the Queen's gambit.  I think Anand and Kramnik had a lot of Slav and semi-Slav positions in their championship a couple years ago.
moves.3. Nc3 Nf6: Here I just took, thinking black would take cxd.
moves.4. cxd5 Nxd5: This move is not what I would call classy, in fact I would say that it lacks class, and I would embarrass myself if I played it.  Since it asks for simplifications, it is aesthetically unappealing.
moves.5. e4: But I try and prop by game up by playing with some class.  This e4 here immediately reasserts the desire for individuation if nxc3.
moves.5... Nxc3: And he does, and here I think I have a great move prepared.
moves.6. bxc3: Now that was a classy move from white.  I think white is going to have a lot of great attacking possibilities here with the bishops going naturally to b2 and d3, and maybe a gallant f4 break.
moves.6... e6: This looks like another subpar move.  I think e5 may have been a lot better.
moves.7. Nf3: Under no time pressure, I play nf3 before just f3.
moves.7... Be7: This move looks slow, safe and uninspired.
moves.8. Bd3: As you can see, the white position develops itself very naturally.  I can not help my courtly charm.  But will I prove a salacious rogue?
moves.8... O-O: I think my development problem is almost solved, and I may be able to start attacking as early as the next move, which will only be move 10.
moves.9. O-O Nd7: My old-world good manners and obvious noble bloodstock are just too much here.  I play a marvelously civilized nd2.
moves.10. Nd2 Nf6 11. f4: He is a bold but comely rapscallion.  This is just a beautiful looking move.
moves.11... h6: Okay, some maybe my opponent wasn't that great in this game.
moves.12. Nc4: Maybe this knight idea isn't that brilliant.  Maybe just e5 or f5 would've been quicker and more to the point.
moves.12... b5 13. Ne5: Okay, so I've got the knight where I want it, but why did I want it there.
moves.13... Bb7 14. f5: Looking at the board, I think you would now say that the white attack is crushing.
moves.14... c5 15. Bxh6: And it's obvious I have been to the best prep schools.
When I am not living in my ancestral castle, I am undoubtedly being waited upon in one of London's finer hotels.
moves.18... gxh6 19. Qg4+ Bg5 20. Qh5: The threat here is simply qg6 after fxe.
moves.20... cxd4 21. fxe6: I can be found in the owner's circle at the Kentucky derby.
moves.21... fxe6 22. Qg6+ Kh8 23. Rf7: And I can't help the class.  If rxf7 then nxf7 is a beautiful mate.
